facts.text: Four writ petitions filed under Article 32: Nos. 215, 228, 251 and 256 of 1966 challenging validity of sections of Bombay Town Planning Act, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 215, 228, 251 and 256 of 1966. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioners are owners of plots of land in Greater Bombay with grievances regarding development plan under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mitter, J. This is a group of four writ petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution. The companymon attack in all these petitions is against the validity of certain sections of the Bombay Town Planning Act, 1954

facts.text: In WP No. 215 of 1966, petitioner's land earmarked for public purpose of a park in Development Plan.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 215 of 1966, the petitioners companyplaint is as regards his land being earmarked for the public purpose of a park in the Development Plan prepared under the Act.

facts.text: Executive Engineer Planning of Municipal Corporation of Bombay ordered on 11th August 1964 that lands in WP 215 were needed for park.

anchor.surface_text: He seeks to, prevent the respondents from giving effect to the said designation of lands in the Development Plan and in particular, to have the third respondents order i.e. the Executive Engineer  Planning   of the Municipal Corporation of Bombay  dated 11th August, 1964

facts.text: In WP 228 of 1966, petitioners' land designated for recreation centre and green belt in P Ward development plan.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 228 of 1966 the prayer is that the designation of the petitioners land as being earmarked for recreation centre and for green belt in the development plan of P Ward of the City of Greater Bombay should be removed

facts.text: Petitioners in WP 228 own land bearing S. No. 70, Hissa Nos. 4, 5 and 6 comprising 31,641 sq. yds. in village Pahadi at Goregaon.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners in this case are two persons who claim to be owners of land bearing S. No. 70, Hissa Nos. 4, 5 and 6 companyprising an aggregate area of 31,641 sq. yds. approximately in village Pahadi at Goregaon in Greater Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioners in WP 228 applied on January 2, 1962 for permission to change land to industrial use and construct factory shed.

anchor.surface_text: Their case is that they had applied through their architect on January 2, 1962 for permission to change the existing user of their lands by putting them to industrial use and had written a letter to the Municipal Commissioner of Bombay

facts.text: Executive Engineer Development Plan intimated on January 27, 1962 no commencement certificate for WP 228 petitioners' factory shed due to green belt and roads.

anchor.surface_text: On January 27, 1962 the Executive Engineer, Development Plan, intimated the petitioners that as a major portion of the proposed factory shed intended to be companystructed fell outside the heavy industrial zone in the green belt area

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed Misc Petition No. 256 of 1962 on September 7, 1963 setting aside refusal dated January 27, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed up by a writ petition in the High Court of Bombay being Miscellaneous Petition No. 256 of 1962 challenging the said refusal as illegal and invalid. By order dated September 7, 1963 the High Court of Bombay allowed the petitioners application

facts.text: Development plan for D Ward adopted by resolution No. 1173 on December 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The development plan for Greater Bombay  D Ward  was adopted by the first respondent by resolution No. 1173 on December 19, 1963.

facts.text: Development plan for remaining wards including P Ward published on January 9, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On January 9, 1964 the development plan for the remaining wards including Ward P was published by the second respondent in the name of the first respondent.

facts.text: List of sites reserved for public purposes submitted on February 8, 1964 showing petitioners' lands for recreation centre.

anchor.surface_text: the list of sites reserved for public purposes was for the first time submitted by the second respondent to the Development Committee on February 8, 1964 showing for the first time that a major portion of the petitioners lands were earmarked for a recreation centre.

facts.text: Resolution No. 343 approved on July 2, 1964 designating land for recreation centre.

anchor.surface_text: This list was recommended for acceptance by the Committee to the first respondent on June 24, 1964 and approved by resolution No. 343 on July 2, 1964

facts.text: Bombay High Court rejected petition No. 248 of 1964 on July 6, 1964; appeal No. 42 of 1964 rejected August 12, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This matter was again taken up to the High Court of Bombay by way of petition No. 248 of 1964 challenging the refusal of the first and second respondents to modify the development plan. This was rejected in limine by the High Court on July 6, 1964. The appeal therefrom being No. 42 of 1964 was also rejected on August 12, 1964.

facts.text: Assistant Engineer rejected construction proposal on January 25, 1965 and February 13, 1965 for green belt and playgrounds.

anchor.surface_text: The third respondent i.e. the Assistant Engineer, Bombay Municipal Corporation by letters dated January 25, 1965 and February 13, 1965 rejected the petitioners proposal for companystruction of factory buildings on their lands on the ground that the lands fell in the reservation for playgrounds and 200 feet wide green belt

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed petition No. 312 of 1965 on July 6, 1965; appeal dismissed April 25, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was rejected in limine by the Bombay High Court on July 6, 1965. An appeal therefrom came for hearing on August 10, 1965 when an order was made by companysent directing the writ petition to be placed for hearing before a Division Bench. Ultimately, however, this was dismissed by judgment dated April 25, 1966.

facts.text: In final plan, of petitioners' 32,000 sq. yds.: 12,144 sq. yds. playground, 804 market, 7,821 road, 1,167 residential, balance 8,702 industrial.

anchor.surface_text: Finally the deponent stated that numberpart of the petitioners lands were earmarked for green belt in the development plan as finally approved by the respondent, that out of 32,000 sq. yds. of the petitioners lands, 12,144 sq. yards of land had been earmarked and reserved for playground 804 sq. yds. had been earmarked and reserved for municipal wholesale market

facts.text: Bombay Town Planning Act, 1954 came into force on April 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into force on April 1, 1957, the first respondent by resolution No. 409 dated July 7, 1958, declared its intention to prepare a development plan

facts.text: Bombay Municipal Corporation declared intention to prepare development plan by resolution No. 409 on July 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into force on April 1, 1957, the first respondent by resolution No. 409 dated July 7, 1958, declared its intention to prepare a development plan for the entire area of Greater Bombay within its jurisdiction.

facts.text: Development plan for P Ward sanctioned by State Government on September 14, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately after companysulting the Special Consulting Surveyor, the Government of Maharashtra sanctioned the development plan in respect of P Ward on September 14, 1966.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the objections raised as to the invalidity of ss. 9, 10, 11, 1.2 and. 13 cannot be upheld. As the petitioners have failed in their attempt to establish any violation of their fundamental rights under the Constitution, the petitions will all be dismissed.
ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 215, 228, 251 and 256 of 1966. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners could re-agitate the matter in this Court on principles analogous to res judicata after failure of petitions in the Bombay High Court

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken, formulated in some detail, that on the failure of the petitions in the Bombay High Court, the petitioners could not re-agitate the matter in this Court on principles analogous to res judicata.

issues.text: Whether the re-designation of petitioners' lands for recreation centre and green belt is without authority of law and violative of fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 19

anchor.surface_text: This re-designation is challenged as being without authority of law and violative of the fundamental rights of the petitioners inter alia under Arts. 14 and 19 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether sections 9 and 10 of the Bombay Town Planning Act are invalid and unconstitutional for empowering modification of the development plan without opportunity to affected persons

anchor.surface_text: ss. 9 and 10 of the Act are invalid... empower the local authority and the State Government to modify the development plan without giving opportunity to persons whose interest might be adversely affected

issues.text: Whether sections 12 and 13 confer unguided and arbitrary power on the local authority to grant or refuse commencement certificates violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the powers and functions of a local authority for purposes of ss. 12 and 13 amongst others were to be exercised... grant or refuse a commencement certificate at his own sweet will and pleasure there being nothing to guide him... refused arbitrarily and there was no provision for any appeal

issues.text: Whether the combined operation of sections 4, 11(3) and 17 allows indefinite delay in acquisition of designated land imposing unreasonable restriction under Article 19

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that by the combined operation of ss. 4 and 11 3 the local authority could easily delay the acquisition of any land designated for public purposes under s. 7 of the Act for 14 years and if resort was had to power, under s. 17... acquisition might be held up indefinitely

issues.text: Whether section 17 of the Bombay Town Planning Act is valid

anchor.surface_text: S. 17 which was attacked in these cases provides that At least once in every ten years from the date on which the last development plan came into force...

arguments.claim: Act provides sufficient guidance for exercise of discretion under ss.12 and 13 from plans, object, and circumstances

arguments.claim: Restrictions in Act reasonable under Art.19(5) given town planning needs, population influx, and public interest

anchor.surface_text: In view of the immensity of the task... period of ten years was not too long... growth of the city and industrialisation... public amenities have to be provided

arguments.claim: Jyoti Pershad precedent applies: guidance in Act suffices against Art.14 challenge

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to a judgment of this Court in Jyoti Pershad v. Administration... enough guidance to the competent authority... reject the contention that s.19 is obnoxious to Art.14

arguments.claim: Manecklal precedent upholds Act: reasonable restrictions under Art.19(5), no Art.14 violation

anchor.surface_text: In Manecklal Chhotalal Ors. v. M. G. Makwana... Court examined the Act... satisfied that the Act imposes only reasonable restrictions... saved under Art.19(5)

arguments.claim: No violation of fundamental rights; ss.9,10,11,12,13 valid

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the objections raised as to the invalidity of ss. 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 cannot be upheld. As the petitioners have failed in their attempt to establish any violation of their fundamental rights

holdings.text: The objections raised as to the invalidity of ss. 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 cannot be upheld; petitioners failed to establish violation of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the objections raised as to the invalidity of ss. 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 cannot be upheld. As the petitioners have failed in their attempt to establish any violation of their fundamental rights under the Constitution, the petitions will all be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act provides guidance from plans, object, circumstances; restrictions reasonable for town planning; follows precedents like Jyoti Pershad and Maneck Lal

holdings.text: ss. 9 and 10 valid; no need for individual opportunity to meet others' objections or notice on modifications

anchor.surface_text: The argument that a person was given no opportunity of meeting the objections raised by others... has no force... authority had to go by the larger interest of the population at large

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall process with publicity, committees, suggestions suffices; authority considers public interest, not individual hearings

holdings.text: Powers under ss. 12 and 13 guided by tentative/final plans, Act's object, circumstances; not unguided or arbitrary, no Art.14 violation

anchor.surface_text: Although s. 12 does not in terms state the grounds... it is clear that the authority had to proceed on the basis of the tentative plan... enough guidance in the Town Planning Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance from Act provisions, development plans, judicial notice of circumstances; analogous to Jyoti Pershad

holdings.text: 10-year period under s.11(3) reasonable, not unreasonable restriction under Art.19

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the complaint that the period of ten years fixed under s.11(3)... not too long... area measuring about 169 sq. miles

holdings.reasoning_summary: Immensity of task for Greater Bombay (169 sq miles), finances, gradual implementation necessary

holdings.text: Restrictions under Act reasonable under Art.19(5) given town planning needs

anchor.surface_text: In view of the immensity of the task... period of ten years was not too long... growth of the city and industrialisation... public amenities have to be provided

holdings.reasoning_summary: Population influx, industrial growth, public amenities require planned development

holdings.text: Act valid as per Maneck Lal precedent; imposes reasonable restrictions saved by Art.19(5)

anchor.surface_text: In Manecklal Chhotalal Ors. v. M. G. Makwana... Court examined the Act... satisfied that the Act imposes only reasonable restrictions... saved under Art.19(5)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court decision examined Act and upheld against Arts.14,19,31 challenges

holdings.text: Not necessary to decide preliminary objection on res judicata

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken... that on the failure of the petitions in the Bombay High Court, the petitioners could not re-agitate the matter... It is not necessary to go into that question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as other grounds dispose of petitions

holdings.text: No views expressed on validity of s.17

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end of the hearing counsel... submitted that s. 17... might be left out... counsel for the respondents were agreeable... We therefore do not express our views about the validity or otherwise of this section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties agreed not to consider in these petitions

precedents.citation: Jyoti Pershad v. Administration for The Union Territory of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: Jyoti Pershad v. Administration for The Union Territory of Delhi 1

precedents.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administration for The Union Territory of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Sufficient guidance in the Act for discretionary powers of authorities; rejection of claims of unguided power violating Art. 14 and unreasonable restrictions on property rights under Art. 19(1)(f)
precedents.cited_holding: There is enough guidance to the competent authority in the use of his discretion under s. 19(1) of the Act and s. 19 is not obnoxious to Art. 14; restrictions are reasonable given the policy and purpose

precedents.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administration for The Union Territory of Delhi

precedents.case_name: Manecklal Chhotalal v. M. G. Makwana
precedents.cited_proposition: Validity of Bombay Town Planning Act; reasonable restrictions under Art. 19(5); no violation of Arts. 14, 19; powers not arbitrary
precedents.cited_holding: The Act imposes only reasonable restrictions, saved under Art. 19(5); Art. 14 not violated

precedents.case_name: Manecklal Chhotalal v. M. G. Makwana

outcome.relief_summary: All writ petitions dismissed; no violation of fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 19 found; validity of sections 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 of the Bombay Town Planning Act upheld.
